message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Swarm navigation of cyborg-insects in unknown obstructed soft terrain
Paper Abstract: Cyborg insects refer to hybrid robots that integrate living insects with miniature electronic controllers to enable robotic-like programmable control. These creatures exhibit advantages over conventional robots in adaption to complex terrain and sustained energy efficiency. Nevertheless, there is a lack of literature on the control of multi-cyborg systems. This research gap is due to the difficulty in coordinating the movements of a cyborg system under the presence of insects' inherent individual variability in their reactions to control input. Regarding this issue, we propose a swarm navigation algorithm and verify it under experiments. This research advances swarm robotics by integrating biological organisms with control theory to develop intelligent autonomous systems for real-world applications.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"},{"title":"Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics"},{"title":"Computational intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_intelligence"},{"title":"Intelligence amplification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Augmented_intelligence"},{"title":"Louis B. Rosenberg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louis_B._Rosenberg"},{"title":"Microbial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbial_intelligence"}]

## Swarm Intelligence Overview

Swarm intelligence (SI) is the collective behavior of decentralized, self-organized systems, natural or artificial.(no content)The expression was introduced by Gerardo Beni and Jing Wang in 1989, in the context of cellular robotic systems.

### Key Characteristics

Swarm intelligence is based on the collective behavior of decentralized, self-organizing systems, typically consisting of a population of simple agents that interact locally with each other and with their environment.(no content)Relatively simple individual rules can produce a large set of complex swarm behaviors.

### Applications

Swarm intelligence has diverse applications across multiple fields:

- **Robotics**: Swarm robotics is the study of how to design independent systems of robots without centralized control.
- **Military**: The U.S. military is investigating swarm techniques for controlling unmanned vehicles.
- **Space**: The European Space Agency is thinking about an orbital swarm for self-assembly and interferometry. NASA is investigating the use of swarm technology for planetary mapping.
- **Data and Networks**: Swarm intelligence has also been applied for data mining and cluster analysis. The use of swarm intelligence in telecommunication networks has also been researched, in the form of ant-based routing.

### Artificial Swarm Intelligence

Artificial Swarm Intelligence (ASI) is method of amplifying the collective intelligence of networked human groups using control algorithms modeled after natural swarms.(no content)The technology connects groups of human participants into real-time systems that deliberate and converge on solutions, and has been used to enable groups of doctors to generate diagnoses with significantly higher accuracy than traditional methods.

Links: [{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Perceptual control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perceptual_control_theory"},{"title":"Social control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_control_theory"},{"title":"Control theory (sociology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory_(sociology)"},{"title":"Affect control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Affect_control_theory"},{"title":"Closed system (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed_system_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Plant (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Classical control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_control_theory"},{"title":"Compensator (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compensator_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Control (optimal control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(optimal_control_theory)"}]

Here are the search results for "control theory":

## Overview

Control theory is a field of control engineering and applied mathematics that deals with the control of dynamical systems.(no content)The aim is to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing any delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

## How It Works

A controller monitors the controlled process variable and compares it with the reference or set point. The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Historical Background

Control theory dates from the 19th century, when the theoretical basis for the operation of governors was first described by James Clerk Maxwell.(no content)Control theory was further advanced by Edward Routh in 1874, Charles Sturm and in 1895, Adolf Hurwitz, who all contributed to the establishment of control stability criteria; and from 1922 onwards, the development of PID control theory by Nicolas Minorsky.

## Applications

Control theory is used in control system engineering to design automation that have revolutionized manufacturing, aircraft, communications and other industries, and created new fields such as robotics.(no content)Although the most direct application of mathematical control theory is its use in control systems engineering, control theory is routinely applied to problems both the natural and behavioral sciences. As the general theory of feedback systems, control theory is useful wherever feedback occurs, making it important to fields like economics, operations research, and the life sciences.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "swarm robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Swarm robotic platforms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotic_platforms"},{"title":"Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics"},{"title":"Ant robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant_robotics"},{"title":"Swarm (novelette) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_(novelette)"},{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"},{"title":"Kilobot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kilobot"},{"title":"S-bot mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S-bot_mobile_robot"},{"title":"Sabine Hauert - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sabine_Hauert"},{"title":"Gerardo Beni - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerardo_Beni"},{"title":"IISc Guidance, Control and Decision Systems Laboratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_Robotics_Laboratory_at_IISc"}]

## Swarm Robotics

Swarm robotic platforms apply swarm robotics in multi-robot collaboration.(no content)Unlike distributed robotic systems in general, swarm robotics emphasizes a large number of robots.

### Key Characteristics

The robots are autonomous, can interact with their surroundings and give feedback to modify the environment, possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities such as wireless transmission systems, do not exploit centralized control, and cooperate with each other to accomplish tasks.(no content)Miniaturization is also a key factor in swarm robotics, as the effect of thousands of small robots can maximize the effect of the swarm-intelligent approach.

### Nature-Inspired Design

The platforms take inspiration from nature, such as collective problem solving mechanisms seen in nature like honey bee aggregation.(no content)The inspiration often comes from nature, especially biological systems, and although there is no centralized control structure, local interactions between agents lead to the emergence of "intelligent" global behavior.

### History

The phrase "swarm robotics" was reported to make its first appearance in 1991 according to Google Scholar, but research regarding swarm robotics began to grow in early 2000s.(no content)One of the first international projects regarding swarm robotics was the SWARM-BOTS project funded by the European Commission between 2001 and 2005.

### Applications

Applications include tasks that demand miniaturization like distributed sensing tasks, and search and rescue missions where swarms of robots could be sent to places that rescue-workers cannot reach safely.(no content)Swarm robotics can also be suited to tasks that demand cheap designs, such as mining or agricultural shepherding tasks.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Swarm robotic platforms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotic_platforms"},{"title":"Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics"},{"title":"Ant robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant_robotics"},{"title":"Swarm (novelette) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_(novelette)"},{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"},{"title":"Kilobot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kilobot"},{"title":"S-bot mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S-bot_mobile_robot"},{"title":"Sabine Hauert - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sabine_Hauert"},{"title":"Gerardo Beni - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerardo_Beni"},{"title":"IISc Guidance, Control and Decision Systems Laboratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_Robotics_Laboratory_at_IISc"}]

## Swarm Robotics

Swarm robotic platforms apply swarm robotics in multi-robot collaboration.(no content)Unlike distributed robotic systems in general, swarm robotics emphasizes a large number of robots.

### Key Characteristics

The robots are autonomous, can interact with their surroundings and give feedback to modify the environment, possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities such as wireless transmission systems, do not exploit centralized control, and cooperate with each other to accomplish tasks.(no content)Miniaturization is also a key factor in swarm robotics, as the effect of thousands of small robots can maximize the effect of the swarm-intelligent approach.

### Nature-Inspired Design

The platforms take inspiration from nature, such as collective problem solving mechanisms seen in nature like honey bee aggregation.(no content)The inspiration often comes from nature, especially biological systems, and although there is no centralized control structure, local interactions between agents lead to the emergence of "intelligent" global behavior.

### History

The phrase "swarm robotics" was reported to make its first appearance in 1991 according to Google Scholar, but research regarding swarm robotics began to grow in early 2000s.(no content)One of the first international projects regarding swarm robotics was the SWARM-BOTS project funded by the European Commission between 2001 and 2005.

### Applications

Applications include tasks that demand miniaturization like distributed sensing tasks, and search and rescue missions where swarms of robots could be sent to places that rescue-workers cannot reach safely.(no content)Swarm robotics can also be suited to tasks that demand cheap designs, such as mining or agricultural shepherding tasks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "robot"

Links: [{"title":"Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot"},{"title":"I, Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I,_Robot"},{"title":"Robot series - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_series"},{"title":"Android (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Android_(robot)"},{"title":"History of robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_robots"},{"title":"Mr. Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mr._Robot"},{"title":"The Robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Robots"},{"title":"List of Robot Wars robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Robot_Wars_robots"},{"title":"List of fictional robots and androids - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_fictional_robots_and_androids"},{"title":"Rise of the Robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rise_of_the_Robots"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about robots:

## Definition and Overview

A robot is a machine—especially one programmable by a computer—capable of carrying out a complex series of actions automatically.(no content)A robot can be guided by an external control device, or the control may be embedded within.

## Types and Range

Most robots are task-performing machines, designed with an emphasis on stark functionality, rather than expressive aesthetics.(no content)Robots can be autonomous or semi-autonomous and range from humanoids such as Honda's Advanced Step in Innovative Mobility (ASIMO) and TOSY's TOSY Ping Pong Playing Robot (TOPIO) to industrial robots, medical operating robots, patient assist robots, dog therapy robots, collectively programmed swarm robots, UAV drones such as General Atomics MQ-1 Predator, and even microscopic nanorobots.

## History

The term "robot" was first used in a play published by the Czech Karel Čapek in 1920. R.U.R. (Rossum's Universal Robots) was a satire, robots were manufactured biological beings that performed all unpleasant manual labor.(no content)The first uses of modern robots were in factories as industrial robots. These industrial robots were fixed machines capable of manufacturing tasks which allowed production with less human work.

## Robotics Field

The branch of technology that deals with the design, construction, operation, and application of robots, as well as computer systems for their control, sensory feedback, and information processing is robotics. These technologies deal with automated machines that can take the place of humans in dangerous environments or manufacturing processes, or resemble humans in appearance, behavior, or cognition.

Web search results for query: "algorithm navigation path planning"

Links: [{"title":"Any-angle path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Any-angle_path_planning"},{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Pathfinding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathfinding"},{"title":"A* search algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A*_search_algorithm"},{"title":"D* - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D*"},{"title":"Theta* - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theta*"},{"title":"Probabilistic roadmap - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probabilistic_roadmap"},{"title":"Wavefront expansion algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavefront_expansion_algorithm"},{"title":"Multi-agent pathfinding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_pathfinding"}]

I've performed a web search for "algorithm navigation path planning" and found comprehensive information about this topic. Here's what I discovered:

## Overview

Path planning is solved by many different algorithms, which can be categorized as sampling-based and heuristics-based approaches.

## Key Algorithm Categories

**A* Algorithm**: A* is a graph traversal and pathfinding algorithm that is used in many fields of computer science due to its completeness, optimality, and optimal efficiency. Given a weighted graph, a source node and a goal node, the algorithm finds the shortest path from source to goal.

**Any-Angle Path Planning**: Any-angle path planning algorithms are pathfinding algorithms that search for a Euclidean shortest path between two points on a grid map while allowing the turns in the path to have any angle. The result is a path that cuts directly through open areas and has relatively few turns.

**D* Algorithm**: D* is any one of three related incremental search algorithms: The original D* by Anthony Stentz, Focused D* which combines ideas of A* and the original D*, and D* Lite which is an incremental heuristic search algorithm.

**Theta***: Theta* is an any-angle path planning algorithm that is based on the A* search algorithm. It can find near-optimal paths with run times comparable to those of A*.

## Applications

Any-angle path planning algorithms are useful for robot navigation and real-time strategy games where more optimal paths are desirable.

These algorithms vary in their approach to efficiency, optimality, and specific use cases like real-time navigation, unknown environments, and multi-agent scenarios.

Excellent! All tasks completed successfully. Here's a summary:

## Summary

I've successfully analyzed the paper "Swarm navigation of cyborg-insects in unknown obstructed soft terrain" and extracted 5 key triples:

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (the paper proposes a novel swarm navigation algorithm)

**Triples Extracted:**
1. **Swarm robotics** (concept) - PROPOSES: The paper advances this field by integrating biological organisms with control theory
2. **Control theory** (concept) - USES: Essential for designing programmable control mechanisms for the cyborg insects
3. **Robot** (concept) - USES: Cyborg insects are hybrid robots offering advantages over conventional robots
4. **Swarm intelligence** (concept) - USES: Underpins the coordination mechanisms for cohesive multi-cyborg operation
5. **Motion planning** (task) - USES: The swarm navigation algorithm addresses motion planning challenges in complex terrain

All validation checks passed, confirming:
- ✅ At least 1 "proposes" relation (required for contribution papers)
- ✅ Multiple "uses" relations (papers always build on existing work)
